data.text:
Registration is now open for the ABHMS Center for Continuous Learning online course Being Baptist: History, Identity & Polity. Over six consecutive weeks beginning September 3, the new cohort will explore the roots of Baptist history, the relationships between different Baptist groups, and the distinctive convictions of Baptist identity.

​

The Rev. Dr. Rebecca Irwin-Diehl, director of the ABHMS Center for Continuous Learning, shared that the course is “specially designed for those seeking ordination in American Baptist Churches USA, but also offers a great learning experience for Baptist history buffs or learners curious about Baptist history and identity and what difference it makes in today’s world.”

​

Learners will engage in independent study and meet collectively as a class each week via Zoom. In addition, the course features guest lecturers delivering webinars viewable on demand. Scheduled presenters include renowned scholars of Baptist history and polity and seasoned pastors and ministry leaders currently applying Baptist identity in their respective contexts.

Upon course completion, learners should be able to trace and analyze the relationships between different Baptist groups in North America, compare their own church’s Baptist identity with that of other Baptist groups, and apply Baptist doctrine in faith-based, community and political contexts, according to Irwin-Diehl, the lead instructor.

​

Among the texts woven into the course are Wayne E. Croft Sr.’s “A History of the Black Baptist Church: I Don’t Feel No Ways Tired” (Judson Press, 2020), Everett C. Goodwin’s “Down by the Riverside: A Brief History of Baptist Faith” (Judson Press, 2002), Norman H. Maring and Winthrop S. Hudson’s “Baptist Manual of Polity & Practice, 2nd rev. edition,” edited by David Gregg (Judson Press, 2012), and Walter B. Shurden’s “The Baptist Identity: Four Fragile Freedoms” (Smyth & Helwys, 1993).

Being Baptist fulfills the Baptist polity educational requirement for ordination candidates in several American Baptist regions. Successful participants will receive a certificate of completion and, where applicable, will earn 3.0 clergy Continuing Education Units.

To learn more about Being Baptist: History, Identity & Polity and to register, visit the CCL website. If you have specific questions, please contact ccl@abhms.org.

​

The ABHMS Center for Continuous Learning provides high-quality educational opportunities for Baptist leaders and laity. Its mission is to equip individuals with the knowledge and skills required to lead and serve effectively in their communities.

NOTICE OF PASTOR VACANCY AT EBENEZER BAPTIST CHURCH

RICHMOND, VIRGINIA

​

The historic Ebenezer Baptist Church of Jackson Ward in Richmond, Virginia is seeking a Senior Pastor to lead this traditional Baptist congregation into the next phase of the 21st century. Applying candidate must embody pastoral characteristics that are grounded in the tenets of the American Baptist Churches of the South (ABCOTS), the Baptist General Convention of Virginia, and the Shiloh Baptist Association, have a deeply rooted biblical foundation in the historical, theological, and socio-political consciousness of the Black Church, and exhibit a passionate commitment to social justice, as well as community and spiritual development of a diverse member demographic.

Ebenezer Baptist Church has existed for 166 years at the corner of Leigh and Judah streets proclaiming the Good News of Jesus Christ. The church building was dedicated on May 30, 1858. Its membership was composed of 188 “slave” and “free” Blacks. The name “Ebenezer” was adopted for the new church, in place of “Third African”. As a historic congregation, Ebenezer takes immense pride in supporting the establishment of the first Black YMCA in Richmond, the first public school for Black children in Richmond, and Hartshorn Memorial College, which later merged with Virginia Union University. Our congregation recently established two endowments – the Ebenezer Community Empowerment Fund and the Henderson-Armwood Endowment for Sacred Music and Arts. The new senior pastor will play a critical role in moving this philanthropic ministry forward.

Ebenezer seeks a leader whose pastoral vision mirrors the church’s mission to love all people and empower our community through the gospel of Jesus Christ through leadership in the areas of worship, Christian education and faith formation, pastoral care, church administration, and community engagement.

QUALIFICATIONS, EXPERIENCE AND EXPERTISE.

An ideal candidate will be or possess the following qualifications:

Demonstrate gifted preaching and teaching abilities.

Be of strong Christian character with moral integrity beyond reproach

Possesses a friendly, helpful, sincere attitude.

An ordained minister recognized (or qualified to be recognized) by the American Baptist churches U.S.A.

A graduate of an accredited theological institution with a Master of Divinity degree or equivalent graduate degree in religion (Master of Theology, Master of Arts in Religion, Master of Sacred Theology, etc.)

At least five years of verifiable experience as an assistant pastor, associate pastor, or senior pastor in a Baptist congregation.

At least one unit of Clinical Pastoral Education, two units are preferred.

Ability to lead within the framework of the Church By-Laws.

Strong Finance and Administrative Management acumen

Maintain and strengthen connections with American Baptist denominational partners at the regional and national levels.

Understands intergenerational and cultural nuances of the church membership and community.

The Senior Pastor of Ebenezer Baptist Church is head of the clergy and ministerial staff, administrative staff, and Music Ministry staff. The pastor is accountable to the congregation through the Board of Administration, which consists of all church ministries chairs and committee chairs.

HOW TO APPLY.

Please prepare the following items and submit them in a single email transmission to recruiting@ebenezerrva.org. Incomplete application packages will not be considered. All materials sent to the Ebenezer Baptist Church Pastoral Search Committee will be kept confidential and are non-returnable to applicants. Ebenezer Baptist Church shall not discriminate based on race, color, religion, gender, age, or sexual orientation. All submissions are due on or before September 30, 2024.

Interested candidate should send

Resume that includes your education, licenses and certifications, relevant ministerial experience, publications, honors, and awards -3 page maximum

Cover Letter that describes your approach to pastoral ministry and explains why you believe God is leading you to Ebenezer – 2 page maximum

Sermon Recording Link to a previously recorded sermon on YouTube, Facebook, or church website that is the best representation of your preaching style, if available

Transcripts: undergraduate and graduate school transcripts (electronic copies are acceptable

Multiple references with verifiable contact information.
